citations.narrative:
The primary enclosure holding three beavers did not adequately contain the animals. In April of this year, the male beaver
was able to climb out of the enclosure over the primary and barrier fence and then got through the perimeter fence.
Despite all search efforts the beaver was hit by a car and killed about a month later. Housing facilities must be structurally
sound and contain the animals for their safety. The facility has since made modifications to the beaver primary enclosure
fence to ensure containment for the remaining beavers.

The facility must put in place mitigation efforts to control pests around the animal enclosures. This includes the otters and
Pallas cat. There was an abundance of flies in the otter holding directly around the feces and an abundance of flies
around the diet for the Pallas cat that was not eaten. A safe and effective program for the control of insects needs to be
maintained for the welfare of the animals.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within (2 ) more inspection(s) or by September 2, 2025 or the applicant will forfeit the
license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License
Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
3.125(a)  Critical Repeat
   
Facilities, general. 
The primary enclosure holding three beavers did not adequately contain the animals. In April of this year, the male beaver 
was able to climb out of the enclosure over the primary and barrier fence and then got through the perimeter fence. 
Despite all search efforts the beaver was hit by a car and killed about a month later. Housing facilities must be structurally 
sound and contain the animals for their safety. The facility has since made modifications to the beaver primary enclosure 
fence to ensure containment for the remaining beavers. 
3.131(d) 
   
Sanitation. 
The facility must put in place mitigation efforts to control pests around the animal enclosures. This includes the otters and 
Pallas cat. There was an abundance of flies in the otter holding directly around the feces and an abundance of flies 
around the diet for the Pallas cat that was not eaten. A safe and effective program for the control of insects needs to be 
maintained for the welfare of the animals. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within (2 ) more inspection(s) or by September 2, 2025 or the applicant will forfeit the 
license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License 
Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
